title: Robbie Williams Reflects on Success, Mental Health, and British Culture
summary: Robbie Williams, a renowned British singer with over three decades in the entertainment industry, has achieved a significant milestone with his new album Britpop, which marks his 16th number one album, surpassing the previous record held by the Beatles. As he embarks on his Long 90s tour, playing in smaller venues reminiscent of his early solo career, Williams reflects on British cultural tendencies. He notes that British people often devalue their own successes, a habit he aims to counter by fully embracing this achievement. The album features collaborations with former Take That bandmate Gary Barlow, Gaz Coombes of Supergrass, and Tony Iommi from Black Sabbath. Williams also opens up about his past struggles with depression during the Britpop era of the 1990s, a time of professional triumph but personal turmoil. He describes how mental illness prevented him from experiencing joy despite numerous successes. Looking back, he views the 1990s as a culturally rich decade, contrasting it with more homogenized recent years. Additionally, Williams discusses how becoming a father in 2012 helped him find purpose and responsibility, alleviating past stage fright and personal challenges.

background_read: Robbie Williams rose to fame as a member of the British boy band Take That in the early 1990s before launching a highly successful solo career. The Britpop era, spanning the mid-1990s, was characterized by a resurgence of British guitar music and cultural pride, with bands like Oasis, Blur, and Pulp leading the movement. Mental health awareness has grown in recent years, with many celebrities speaking out about issues like depression and anxiety. British culture often includes self-deprecation, where people downplay their achievements, which Robbie discusses in this context. Fatherhood and personal responsibility are common themes in discussions about life changes and well-being.
